# NYC Taxi fare amount prediction project

Eunhee Lim
### Import relevant libraries and packages for project

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import sklearn
import seaborn as sns
import geopandas as gpd
import datetime as dt
import time
from math import sin, cos, sqrt, atan2, radians
from shapely.geometry import Polygon

First, I will explore the time it takes to load training data. Train.csv file contrains 55M rows of data. Opening the full file takes about 7 minutes. In order to expedite the data exploration and analysis, I will first work with 10,000 rows of data which takes about 1 second to load.

start = time.time()
print("hello")
df_train = pd.read_csv('/Users/prq-210/ML bootcamp/train.csv', nrows=10000, parse_dates=['pickup_datetime'])
end = time.time()
print(end - start)

### 1.1 Preliminary examination of raw data

I will look at the first five rows of data using .head(). I see that there are 8 features including

    key
    fare_amount
    pickup_datetime
    pickup_longitude
    pickup_latitude
    dropoff_longitude
    dropoff_latitude
    passenger_count

source:
There are a few abnormalities detected from .describe().

    Fare amount:       Max value of $180 seems a bit too high given (mean, std) of (11.2, 9.6). 
    Pickup_longitude:  City of New York should have longitude values ranging from -75~-73. 
    Pickup_latitude:   City of New York should have latitude values ranging from 40~41. 
    Dropoff_longitude: City of New York should have longitude values ranging from -75~-73. 
    Dropoff_latitude:  City of New York should have latitude values ranging from 40~41. 
    Passenger count:   Number of passengers should be between 1 and 6. 
    
I will need extra caution in looking at distributions as I have loaded 10,000 rows out of 55M rows. I should be careful that there could be more outliers/wrong/missing data in the rest of the raw dataset.

### 1.2.1 Fare amount

Distrubition of fare amount shows that most of the trips are below $50.


From closer examination below, we see that row corresponding to $180 has same pickup and dropoff locations. This is likely a wrong data.

text/plain:
key                  2013-01-16 20:19:58.0000001
fare_amount                                  180
pickup_datetime        2013-01-16 20:19:58+00:00
pickup_longitude                        -74.4293
pickup_latitude                             40.5
dropoff_longitude                       -74.4293
dropoff_latitude                            40.5
passenger_count                                1
Name: 1335, dtype: object

source:
### 1.2.1 Pickup and dropoff locations

From plots below, we see that many of the longitude and latitude values are out side of range below, indicating that these rows should be discarded.

        NYC Longitude range: -75~-73
        NYC Latitude range : 40~41

### 1.2.2 Passenger count

The total number of passenger per taxi cannot exceed 6 people. While examination in this MWS looks OK, there could be outliers in the raw data.

### 1.2.3 Missing values

Lastly, I will check if there are any missing values in the dataset. Although this MWS has no missing values, there could be missing values in the raw data.

text/plain:
passenger_count      0
dropoff_latitude     0
dropoff_longitude    0
pickup_latitude      0
pickup_longitude     0
pickup_datetime      0
fare_amount          0
key                  0
dtype: int64

source: # Check to see if there are any missing values in data

## 1.3 Cleaning data

Here, rows with missing values, outliers, etc will be removed from the working set.

# Drop rows with missing values, wrong values, outliers, etc
df_train = df_train.drop(df_train[df_train.isnull().any(1)].index, axis = 0)
df_train = df_train.drop(df_train[df_train['fare_amount']<0].index, axis=0)
df_train = df_train.drop(df_train[df_train['fare_amount']>100].index, axis=0)

df_train = df_train.drop(df_train[df_train['pickup_longitude']<-75].index, axis=0)
df_train = df_train.drop(df_train[df_train['pickup_longitude']>-73].index, axis=0)

df_train = df_train.drop(df_train[df_train['dropoff_longitude']<-75].index, axis=0)
df_train = df_train.drop(df_train[df_train['dropoff_longitude']>-73].index, axis=0) 


df_train = df_train.drop(df_train[df_train['pickup_latitude']<40].index, axis=0)
df_train = df_train.drop(df_train[df_train['pickup_latitude']>41].index, axis=0)

df_train = df_train.drop(df_train[df_train['dropoff_latitude']<40].index, axis=0)
df_train = df_train.drop(df_train[df_train['dropoff_latitude']>41].index, axis=0)

df_train = df_train.drop(df_train[df_train['passenger_count']<1].index, axis=0)
df_train = df_train.drop(df_train[df_train['passenger_count']>6].index, axis=0)

## 1.4 Preparing data

Here, cleaned data will be made into more analysis friendly data.

### 1.4.1 Sepearting datetime feature to year, month, day, and hour

This will allow us to visualize taxi ride/fare trend for each year, month, day, and hour. Especially, hour data can provide helpful insight on fare dependence on time of the day (i.e. due to traffic).

# Separating features: year, month, day, hour
df_train['pickup_year']= df_train['pickup_datetime'].dt.year
df_train['pickup_month']= df_train['pickup_datetime'].dt.month
df_train['pickup_date']= df_train['pickup_datetime'].dt.day
df_train['pickup_hour']= df_train['pickup_datetime'].dt.hour

source:
### 1.4.2 Calculating trip distance

        From pickup_longitude, pickup_latidue, dropoff_longitude, and dropoff_latitude, we can apply Haversine method to calculate distance traveled. This feature could be helpful in understanding fare amount per distance traveled.

# Haversine method for calculating distance from longitude and latitude values

def trip_distance(x): 
    R = 6369 # Earth's radius near NYC, Unit = [km]

    lat_1 = radians(x['pickup_latitude'])
    lat_2 = radians(x['dropoff_latitude'])
    long_1 =radians(x['pickup_longitude'])
    long_2 = radians(x['dropoff_longitude'])

    delta_long = long_2-long_1
    delta_lat = lat_2-lat_1

    a= (sin(delta_lat / 2))**2 + cos(lat_1) * cos(lat_2) * (sin(delta_long / 2))**2
    c = 2 * atan2(sqrt(a), sqrt(1 - a))

    distance = R * c
    return distance

df_train['distance'] = df_train.apply(trip_distance, axis=1)
I will remove any rows with distance less than 500m.
Here, I will see if the next minimum distance is a acceptable row or not based on fare amount, which should be the base fare. The fare_amount is $4.5 for 500m trip, which seems reasonable.

source:
def fare_per_distance(x): 

    fare = x['fare_amount']
    distance = x['distance']

    fare_per_distance = fare/distance
    return fare_per_distance

df_train['fare_per_distance'] = df_train.apply(fare_per_distance, axis=1)

df_train.fare_per_distance.describe()

### 1.4.3 Creating GeoDataFrame from existing DataFrame

Here, I will create a GeoDataFrame for train MWS in order to be able to work with geometries. There can be only one active 'geoseries' per GeoDataFrame. Since we have both pickup location and dropoff location, I will have to convert pickup location first and then convert the dropoff location.
    
Additionally, I will load a file contraining the five NYC borough (Manhatten, Queens, Stanten Island, Bronx, Brooklyn) boundary information, and spatially join the two geometry. By doing this, I will create two new features 'pickup_boro' and 'dropoff_boro'. My plan is to use this information to assign toll fee features in the future. This has not been implemented yet.

# Making df_train from dataframe to geodataframe
# First, create geoseries from pickup location.
gdf_train = gpd.GeoDataFrame(
    df_train, geometry=gpd.points_from_xy(df_train.pickup_longitude, df_train.pickup_latitude))
gdf_train.crs = {'init' :'epsg:4326'}
gdf_train.head()

Loading ny_borough_boundary shapefile and exploring data. Data format is epsg:4326 (longitude and latitude form) and the data contains:

    boro_name: borough name
    geometry: multipolygon defining the boundary of the borough

# GeoDataFrame with geographical boundaries of New York boroughs
boro_full = gpd.read_file('/Users/prq-210/ML bootcamp/ny_borough_boundary.shp')
boros = boro_full[['boro_name', 'geometry']].set_index('boro_name')
boros.geometry.crs

gdf_train_with_boros.rename_geometry('pickup_geometry', inplace=True)
gdf_train_with_boros = gdf_train_with_boros.rename(columns={'index_right': 'pickup_boro'})
gdf_train_with_boros.crs = {'init' :'epsg:4326'}

    gdf_train_with_boros, geometry=gpd.points_from_xy(gdf_train_with_boros.dropoff_longitude, gdf_train_with_boros.dropoff_latitude))

### Next steps

Questions to answer:
    1. Does time of the day affect fare amount?
    2. Does travel distance affect fare amount?
    3. Does time of the day affect fare amount per distance?
